awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Network Protection under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project focuses on improving the security of the population in the case of a terrorist threat, and how integrated modeling can be used (1) to improve scientific understanding of human decision-making in adversarial contexts, and (2) in the design of allocation policies and best practices for protection of soft targets, i.e., public transit facilities, places of mass gathering, and their users. It involves theoretical and computational research that will explore the foundations of infrastructure protection technologies through integrated modeling and optimization and will develop new methods and tools to support real-time emergency management and policy development. The project has a wide range of applications from homeland security and law enforcement to military applications. This research is transformational since it brings a fresh vision to risk management and sensing/control networks for security. The most significant impact of the research is expected to be to public facilities, campuses, school buildings and its users by providing support to first responders in decision making about prevention and deterrence of terrorist attacks as well as minimization of damage during an attack. Results of the work will be communicated with the major regional players, including NY/NJ Port Authority, NJ Transit, NJ Department of Homeland Security and NJDOT.  The adversarial decision making models and virtual game infrastructure that will result from the research are also applicable to other areas such as training law enforcement personnel to prevent gang violence and training campus police. This study also seeks to have a broad impact, especially, in regard to the integration of research and education; it will provide the basis for a Ph.D. dissertation and will provide support to mentor a postdoctoral associate in information sciences and its application to security. The results of the research will establish the framework for a comprehensive book on infrastructure protection games to be used by students as well as practitioners.

The key features of the research project are (i) closed form analytical solutions, (ii) game models that explore the ways in which the uncertainty and incomplete information about the adversary type, attack type and power, can be exploited by the players, (iii) a patrolling game that incorporates detection probability and a people flow model representing moving targets, and (iv) a virtual game built inside an immersive virtual world designed to both collect data about the players' behavior and to validate the game models using metrics such as the expected damage, the fraction of unsuccessful attacks, etc. The objectives of the research are to (1) Develop stochastic network protection game algorithms to be used by the defenders, together with current technologies, in planning for emergency preparedness, for prevention of terrorist or cyber attacks to reduce the loss of valuable assets; (2) Design a virtual game involving the key elements of the above models in order to collect information about the behavior of various players of the game; (3) Test models for real player behavior in a controlled setting via virtual games  to verify and refine models for human subject behavior in the stochastic games. These objectives will be accomplished by adapting resource allocation game models to the virtual game. Realistic player behavior data will be collected to validate the models. The anticipated results of this research are both analytical and relevant to practitioners, such as emergency management agencies, police, etc. The research makes contributions to i) stochastic modeling of adversarial policies in man-made emergencies; ii) stochastic game theory for partially observable systems; iii) decision-making in defending critical infrastructure; iv) educating future first responders in homeland security and resource allocation.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF supported research program focuses on improving the security of the population in the case of a terrorist threat, and how integrated modeling can be used (1) to improve scientific understanding of human decision-making in adversarial contexts, and (2) in the design of allocation policies and best practices for protection of soft targets, i.e., public transit facilities, places of mass gathering, and their users. It involves theoretical and computational research that explores the foundations of infrastructure protection technologies through integrated modeling and optimization and develops new methods and tools to support real-time emergency management and policy development. 

Intellectual Merit - This research has a wide range of applications from homeland security and law enforcement to military applications. The successful implementation of the five tasks in this research has (1) provided a solid scientific foundation for infrastructure protection that can be used by various agencies, together with current technologies, in planning for emergency preparedness, for prevention of terrorist or cyber attacks to reduce the loss of valuable assets, (2) advanced the state-of-the-art on security games by contributing new concepts, models, and algorithms, (3) offered fundamental insights that can be transformed to many other security settings, and (4) provided vast amount of data about agents' behavior playing virtual attack/defend games built inside an immersive virtual world.

The research outcomes and findings from each task are summarized as follows:

(1) We have proposed static network protection game models,  and derived  the best defense strategies when complete information is available, and also when only partial information is available. (2) We have proposed dynamic patrolling game models and developed algorithms to find the best defense strategies. These models have been applied to an urban rail network and the best patroller allocation strategies are derived. (3) We have extended the proposed game models to the cyber-security area, and developed best resource allocation policies for providing secure communication. (4) We have developed 2D and 3D virtual games, mimicking some of our protection game models, in which human agents can make attack and defense decisions. We have used the game playthrough data to analyze the attackers' behavior in choosing targets. (5) Finally, we have used the playthrough data to assess the performance of human agents against the artificial-defender agent, which is implementing the best defense strategy.  

Broader Impacts - The models, algorithms and analytical tools developed in this research program have contributed to address the challenges in protecting public facilities, campuses, school buildings and its users by providing support for first responders in decision making about prevention and deterrence of terrorist attacks as well as minimization of damage during an attack.

Two Rutgers doctoral students have been supported on this research. One doctoral student is nearing completion of his dissertation, and the other is currently in the proposal stage as the direct results from this project. These students were exposed to game-theoretic infrastructure and cyber security problems, and trained to conduct extensive literature review, study game theory, identify research problems, develop models, and derive closed form or computational solution algorithms. As a result, the two doctoral students collectively have five high-quality journal manuscripts. Overall, this project has produced 7 refereed journal publications in top journals. Dr. Baykal-Gursoy and her students have disseminated their research findings by making 10 presentations at multiple national and international conferences. The experiences helped the students to improve their presentation skills, and provided them with excellent networking opportunities for their future careers. 

One Rutgers master and one undergraduate students have also been supported to work on this research, including one from underrepresented groups. These students have been exposed to game theory and virtual game design, and together with one of the doctoral students they have worked on developing 2D and 3D virtual games. Moreover, over four years, one Rutgers undergraduate student supported by the Douglass Project, and four Rutgers undergraduate students supported by the Aresty Research Assistant program have worked on developing and analyzing playable games. Two of the undergraduate students are from underrepresented groups. These students have had opportunities to demonstrate the virtual games and present their findings to public during the Rutgers Day, and the Rutgers School of Engineering Open House. In addition, two Rutgers undergraduate senior design groups have worked on security game related projects under the direction of Dr. Baykal-Gursoy. 

The research activities in this project have maintained the collaborations among the two universities and partners. The project meetings provided a great opportunity for all the students and visiting scholars to network and communicate their research findings.
